comment_0:
Now that Eminem is highly prased as a rapper today, I can actually look back and see the deeper meaning of this song. It is very morbid and no doubt one of Eminem's most controversial songs. However if you analyze the overall meaning it's really brillant. First I agree the Stan part means ST as in stalker and AN as in fan, symbolism of Stan. 
When you think about it, a lot of Eminem's songs are about his personal problems as well as society's problems. I think he used himself to represent a society problem, the media and music influencing people. Stan becomes so obsessed with Slim, and lives his life for Slim. I think he's trying to show the person's side rather than the music/media. It almost reminds me of the Columbine Tragedy, many people thought Marilyn Manson's music had an influence on the boys behavior and indirectly caused them to shoot innocent people. I think Eminem is trying to show that music may influence it, it is always initially the person who has the problem and not the music. You can clearly see Stan has mental issues which leads to his suicide and killing of his pregnant girlfriend (when he kills his girlfriend it actually really seems to symbolize Columbine because innocent people were killed because of madness). In the end, you hear Slim saying "You cut your wrists too, I was clowin man, I think you need some help, why you so mad, I don't want you to do some crazy shit." This part is the strongest in saying how you can't literally take all controversial music or use it to blame people's problems.
comment_1:
I think that this song is to send a warning out to his fans. Of course we all know that Eminem's next best talent is stirring up controversy. If you listen to the songs on The Marshall Mathers LP, there are many reoccurrences of a message that says to his fans that a lot of the things he says should not be taken seriously, and that he doesn't really mean what he means.

I think this song is that same warning, except he's trying to use an example of what would happen if you take him too seriously. Stan is writing to Eminem about how he takes everything that Eminem says seriously, and Eminem writes back saying that Stan doesn't really understand him and that Stan should seek some help. Finally, we know what happened to Stan. I think the point of the song was to send out a message to his fans to not take everything he says seriously.
comment_2: like everyone else says the song is really deep it touches the surface of the soul i mean this is where a drunk would have a clear moment of clarity..and someone whos thoughtfully deep..the truth is that em put alot of thought into this song, this definetley came from the heart and it has multiple meanings mainley towards what us the fans think of it you could just say it was a song expressing how it is for a famous person a dealing with all fans which is impossible because you cant satisfy everyone and for someone like em you can only do that through your songs ..one of the points is you cant write just write him or any famous person and expect them too respond because they got a life just like you ..i mean damn all of us are only human..he speaks too us through all of his songs, which show his personality and his life think of it from his concept not just your own.
comment_4: I think that this song shows the "deeper" side of Eminem, he isn't ALL about what people think he is. I also think that this song has more meaning then the obvious.......yes I'm talking about you Kevin..... I think this also goes to say that life isn't as easy for people like Eminem (famous) as some people think it is. But that is just my outlook on it. Thsi song is deep and I think that it will be in peoples minds for a long time to come.
comment_5: I don't think anyone should get offended by the way Stan killed his girlfriend.  Eminem was actually trying to send a real message in this video.  Maybe he could have done it less morbidly, but then, he could have been more morbid, as well.  The point is, if Stan had just killed himself, it would have been sad.  But the fact that he took this poor woman and her baby with him adds to the horrific poignancy of the song.  This song was about pain, about someone trying to find himself by living through another person.  And in the end, when his sanity came crumbling down...well.  The part of the song that hit me the hardest was actually at the very end, when Eminem is writing back and suddenly realizes who Stan was, and you know that maybe (lost cause though he was), if Stan had held out just a little longer, all that death would never have occured.

comment_11:
I think the literal meaning of this is song is obvious. Perhaps there is a little subtle message that Eminem is trying to say that the stuff he says in this lyrics about wanting to hurt himself and others shouldn't be taken seriously, and if you do take it seriously, you're fucking insane, just like Stan. I honestly think the entire song is about Eminem trying to express that not everything he says should be taken as gospel. The fact that in the end he lets his "1# fan" down, and thus inadvertantly causes his death, is kind of like symbolically Eminem is trying to say, "I'm just human like everyone else! I make mistakes! Don't worship me or take what I say seriously!" Perhaps as an emotional response to this incredible amount of fame and perhaps as a response to all the hate he seems to get from parents convinced he's brainwashing their kids. (I don't think the message is to the parents, I think it's to the kids. In the music video, the "Mom" of Stan looks at the boy and it looks like she's trying to convince the 6 year old not to follow in Stan's footsteps...I'm not sure, but it seems like she's probably cursing out Stan and Eminem and telling the boy not to be like them).

The irony at the end, that Eminem actually does reply back to Stan in the end, makes me think...maybe he's trying to say, "I'm human, I make mistakes, but I always try to come through for my fans."

It's definately one of Eminem's best songs.
comment_12: I've been an Eminem fan since the beginning. I can remember rapping his songs when I was 6 years old. Imagine a little Mexican girl that grew up on Led Zeppelin and The Doors rapping Eminem. I don't know why I loved him so much because I didn't really like rap too much. I thought he was great. But then, I remember being in 7th grade as a 12 year old and I found Stan on YouTube, and it's the song that made me /really/ become a fan. I've gotten much farther into rap but he's still my favorite rapper and I know he always will be. This song is haunting and brilliant. Definitely my favorite song of his. It's real and raw and emotional. I don't even know how to describe it accurately because there's so many different great things to say about it.

comment_111:
Eminem gets a lot of crap for his songs and his lyrics,
but they're not really meant to be taken seriously.
And a lot of the time the deeper meaning really does have a good message.
I'm not a huge fan of rap, but Eminem is definitely one of my favorite artists.

His songs never get old.
This one is really intense and morbid,
but I think it's beautiful.
comment_112: I love this song! I think it shows the responsibility an artist unwillingly and undeservedly takes when an unstable person takes thr art they have made and use it to justify or act upon their irrational actions. Stan says he cuts himself too, not understanding that Eminem says that sort of thing just to give drama to his songs, and the same with killing his girlfriend. It's art, and art isn't always pretty but it is an outlet for all sorts of emotions and thoughts, and Stan takes it too literal. It reminds me of John Hinckley Jr. who got obsessed with Taxi Driver and Jodie Foster and tried to assasinate President Ronald Reagan. They take the art and use it in ways that the artists never meant to have them taken. And Eminem has faced criticism for being a bad influence but how can he control how people take his music. And is he responsible? No, but the feeling of guilt and a sick feeling of those who are messed up and mess other peoples' lives and use an artist as a scapegoat or source of inspiration are hard tackles to take on, especially in a song. But Eminem did a great job of it!
comment_113: I think the title of this song is a veiled reference to the character of Stan Marsh on South Park, who is often seen experiencing personal troubles on the show.
comment_114: I am not an Eminem fan in general, and I don't like rap/hip hop as a rule. But this song is awesome. The passion and intensity of Stans anger, leading him to a psychological breakdown, against the chilled out Dido tune in the background ( and, FWIW, he also picks the only bit of Dido I reckon is worth listening to ), against the busy artist, trying to find the time to write to his fans - phenomenal. This is genius.
comment_115:
This song is describing how an obsessive fan becomes so obsessed with his idol not responding and his wife discovers the truth of how much he really loves slim causing him to kill him.

I believe the Dido Chorus Refers to how slim feels about slim.

Stan feels upset because he feels no one understands him and can relate to him , and when he remembers slim and how he can relate to someone and he no longer feels alone.
comment_117: Well, has this happened? Or does he mean something else, like fans Shouldnt be so obsessed, and it will not be long before they do that kindo crazy stuff...?
comment_118:
I love the part where Stan says "Hey Slim, I drank a fifth of vodka, you dare me to drive?"

A direct reference to My Name Is, and completely relevant. Emphasises how much of an obsessed fan that Stan is, by having him actually using Eminem's previous lyrics against him. Eerie.
comment_119:
I think this song really brings out how much Eminem has been through, like how crazy his fans could be, how obsessive and following that they can be; that they will do anything to contact him, meet him, just to know him like a close friend. So rather than just a song, it's a warning to people that listen to his music to not be obsessive and to do crazy crap over him. It's really a matter of how seriously they take his lyrics.

If they take them too seriously, like Stan, they will do crazy things to prove the 'I'm the Number One Fan' fact of life, sort of-thing. If they're here for listening and trying to understand Marshall in a nice, subtle, non-obsessive way, then it'll show them what become obsessive could possibly do to them.

Mostly, it's all to do with whether you're obsessed with Eminem or not for your take on this song.
comment_120: Oh yeah, I forgot to add that Dido and Eminem...never would have thought the combination would work so well, but it really does...Dido's part just becomes more and more creepy as the song progresses due to the dark subject matter of Eminem's lyrics.

comment_128: To give you a bit of insight, Stan is a name generally used as a shortened version of Stanley.
comment_129:
This song is so powerful. It is one of my favorite songs of all time. To most people who are just listening to the song, it probably sounds like some explicit disgusting song by Eminem. Well let me just say that Eminem is misunderstood, especially in this song. When Eminem raps, he lets all his emotions go. His thoughts spill onto his paper. This is good. However, those who idolize Eminem take his words literally, and do some of the stuff he talks about in his songs (ie killing girlfriends and doing drugs). The meaning of this song is simply Eminem stating don't do anything I talk about in my songs if it's negative because most of the time I don't mean it. 
This song is about a fan of Eminem's, Stanley Mitchell (aka Stan. That's where the name of the song comes from). Stan obviously is suffering with depression, or something very similar. He opens up his letters to Eminem by saying how much he idolizes him. For example, "My girlfriend's preganant too I'm about to be a father. If I have a daughter, guess what I'ma call her? I'm gonna name her Bonnie." Stan also states how much he can relate to Eminem. For example, "I heard about your Uncle Ronnie too I'm sorry. I had a friend kill himself over some ___ who didn't want him." He ends the letter on a calm note.
The song progresses to the chorus, and Stan writes another letter. In this letter, Stan becomes more annoyed that his idol (Eminem) still hasn't written or called. He continues to explain to Eminem how much he means to him, and pleads with him to write him back. He ends the letter, and the chorus comes back up again. Then, Stan records a cassette of himself for Eminem while he's really drunk. Stan states in this letter that he tied his girlfriend up and threw her in the trunk. He was on his way to drive off a bridge, basically to commit suicide, and kill his pregnant girlfriend. Stan pretty much states that this wouldn't have happend if Eminem had written him back. And then, this verse ends when Stan drives off the bridge. 
Eminem then finally writes him back. This is where he basically states that Stan shouldn't do what he says in his songs. For example, "I think you and you're girlfriend really need eachother, or maybe you just need to treat her better." Then, right at the end of the verse, Eminem realizes that Stan killed himself, and he could have helped him, if he had just written back sooner.

So anyway, this is what this song means to me. Like I said above, this is one of my favorite songs of all time.. So i've listened to it enough to discet the true meaning.
comment_130: lol,  Stan wasn't even really a fan
comment_131: Sometimes I cry to this song while thinking of my ex. What sticks out is the tea going cold. Mormons can't drink tea. It symbolizes a pleasure I gave up for him as well as him growing cold. "Got out of bed alone." I often text him, "I don't want to go to bed alone." before or after a depressive episode. I normally end up sleeping alone. He said the break up was only temporary while he gets his shit together. I'm like Stan. All I want is a lousy fucking text or call! You say you love me, but do you mean it? "Killed himself over some bitch who didn't want him" sometimes I think about it. I don't always have the will to live, but I don't have the will to die either. He was the only thing that kept my mood stable. The pills don't work by themselves. "Sometimes I even cut myself." I promised him I wouldn't do it anymore. "You could've rescued me from drowning." He could've, but he hasn't yet. Yes, "yet". That sliver of hope. I think about how he would react though if what happened to Stan happened to me. If I had a manic episode, told him to go fuck himself, and ended my life. The pregnant girlfriend in the car is a figment of my imagination. She represents the sanity I have left.
comment_132: I personally believe the song is a metaphor for his internal conflict with Stan representing one of his 3 egos,Marshal mathers,the little brother being Eminem and slim being slim
